problems.title: Burnt Leaf Tips in Cucumbers
problems.description: Cucumber plants exhibit burnt or crispy leaf tips, often due to nutrient burn caused by excessive fertilizer concentration or high light intensity.
symptoms: Burnt or crispy leaf tips
Brown leaf edges
Scorch marks on foliage
possibleCauses: Excessive nutrient concentration
High light intensity
pH imbalance affecting nutrient uptake
solutions: Dilute the nutrient solution
Adjust pH to the optimal range (5.5-6.5)
Provide shading or improve ventilation
problems.adjustmentRecommendation: Reduce the nutrient concentration by 10-15% initially and adjust light exposure if necessary.

problems.title: Curling Tomato Leaves
problems.description: Tomato plants exhibit curling leaf edges, which is often associated with calcium deficiency or overall nutrient imbalances.
symptoms: Leaf edges curling upward
Brown or discolored margins
Distorted leaf shape
possibleCauses: Calcium deficiency
Excess salt buildup
Inconsistent watering
solutions: Increase calcium supplementation
Adjust nutrient ratios
Ensure proper watering and drainage
problems.adjustmentRecommendation: Increase calcium supplementation by 10-15% and consider reducing salt levels if necessary.

problems.title: Cucumber Leaves Curling Under
problems.description: Cucumber leaves curling under can be a sign of over-fertilization or inconsistent watering, leading to imbalanced turgor pressure.
symptoms: Leaves curling under
Wilting
Mild discoloration
possibleCauses: Over-application of fertilizer
Inconsistent moisture levels
Low ambient humidity
solutions: Reduce fertilizer concentration
Maintain a consistent watering schedule
Increase ambient humidity
problems.adjustmentRecommendation: Reduce the nutrient solution strength by 10-20% initially and stabilize the watering schedule.

problems.title: Abnormal Basil Stem Development
problems.description: Basil plants sometimes show abnormal stem development—such as swelling or discoloration—possibly due to fungal infection or overwatering.
symptoms: Swollen or discolored stems
Mushy texture
Stunted growth
possibleCauses: Fungal infection
Overwatering
Poor air circulation
solutions: Improve air circulation
Reduce watering frequency
Apply a fungicide if necessary
problems.adjustmentRecommendation: No specific nutrient adjustment; focus on improving environmental conditions.

problems.title: Yellowing Lettuce Leaves
problems.description: Lettuce plants may develop yellowing leaves, often due to nitrogen deficiency or waterlogging that causes oxygen-deprived roots.
symptoms: General yellowing of leaves
Stunted growth
Premature leaf drop
possibleCauses: Nitrogen deficiency
Overwatering
pH imbalance affecting nutrient uptake
solutions: Increase nitrogen levels in the nutrient mix
Ensure proper drainage
Monitor and adjust pH levels
problems.adjustmentRecommendation: Increase nitrogen levels by approximately 10% initially while improving drainage.

problems.title: Blossom End Rot in Bell Peppers
problems.description: Bell pepper fruits develop blossom end rot, typically caused by calcium deficiency or irregular watering.
symptoms: Dark, sunken spots on the fruit
Fruit distortion
Premature fruit drop
possibleCauses: Calcium deficiency
Irregular watering
Excessive fertilizer application
solutions: Supplement calcium in the nutrient solution
Implement a consistent watering schedule
Adjust fertilizer concentration
problems.adjustmentRecommendation: Increase calcium supplementation by 10-15% initially and standardize watering practices.

problems.title: Strawberry Leaf Scorch
problems.description: Strawberry plants may develop scorched leaf margins due to high light intensity combined with nutrient imbalances.
symptoms: Scorched or brown leaf margins
Wilting
Reduced fruit quality
possibleCauses: Excessive light exposure
High nutrient salt concentration
pH imbalance
solutions: Provide partial shading
Dilute the nutrient solution
Adjust pH gradually
problems.adjustmentRecommendation: Dilute the nutrient solution by about 10% initially and adjust pH in small increments.

problems.title: Spinach Tip Burn
problems.description: Spinach plants can exhibit tip burn, usually due to high salt concentration or uneven water distribution.
symptoms: Brown or burnt tips on leaves
Crisp, dry edges
Uneven growth
possibleCauses: Excessive nutrient concentration
Uneven water distribution
Environmental stress
solutions: Adjust nutrient concentration
Ensure even water delivery
Stabilize environmental conditions
problems.adjustmentRecommendation: Reduce the nutrient solution strength by 10-15% initially.

problems.title: Yellowing Basil Leaves
problems.description: Basil plants may display overall yellowing of leaves, which can be due to micronutrient deficiencies or improper pH levels.
symptoms: Uniform yellowing of foliage
Pale leaf color
Reduced growth
possibleCauses: Micronutrient deficiencies (e.g., iron, magnesium)
Suboptimal pH affecting uptake
solutions: Increase micronutrient concentrations
Adjust pH to within 5.5-6.5
problems.adjustmentRecommendation: Increase micronutrients by around 10% and adjust pH gradually.

problems.title: Tomato Fruit Cracking
problems.description: Tomato fruits may develop cracks on the skin, often due to inconsistent watering and nutrient imbalances affecting cell turgor.
symptoms: Cracked fruit skin
Uneven fruit size
Premature fruit drop
possibleCauses: Inconsistent watering
Nutrient imbalances
solutions: Establish a consistent watering schedule
Balance the nutrient solution
problems.adjustmentRecommendation: Focus primarily on consistent watering; adjust nutrient ratios if imbalances persist.

problems.title: Root Rot in Hydroponic Lettuce
problems.description: Lettuce plants can develop root rot characterized by mushy, brown roots and a foul odor, usually caused by overwatering and poor oxygenation.
symptoms: Mushy, discolored roots
Foul odor from the root zone
Stunted above-ground growth
possibleCauses: Overwatering
Low dissolved oxygen
Pathogenic fungal or bacterial infection
solutions: Improve aeration in the root zone
Reduce watering frequency
Replace contaminated water and media
problems.adjustmentRecommendation: Reduce water volume by 10-15% and enhance root aeration.

problems.title: Algae Growth in Nutrient Reservoir
problems.description: Algae buildup in the nutrient reservoir can reduce nutrient availability and serve as a breeding ground for pathogens.
symptoms: Green or brown slimy deposits on reservoir walls
Turbid water
Unpleasant odor
possibleCauses: Exposure of the reservoir to light
Infrequent cleaning
solutions: Cover the reservoir to block light
Clean the reservoir regularly
Replace water periodically
problems.adjustmentRecommendation: No nutrient adjustment is required; focus on physical remediation.

problems.title: Nutrient Lockout Due to pH Fluctuation
problems.description: Plants may show nutrient deficiency symptoms despite an adequate supply when pH levels are outside the optimal range, leading to nutrient lockout.
symptoms: General chlorosis
Stunted growth
Poor fruit or flower development
possibleCauses: pH levels outside the optimal range (5.5-6.5)
Excess buildup of nutrient salts
solutions: Test and adjust the pH gradually using pH up or pH down solutions
Flush the system periodically to remove salts
problems.adjustmentRecommendation: Adjust pH in small increments (5-10% change) and recheck after 24 hours.

problems.title: Pest Infestation in Hydroponic Systems
problems.description: Pest infestations—such as aphids or whiteflies—can stress hydroponic plants and potentially transmit diseases.
symptoms: Visible insects on leaves
Sticky residue (honeydew)
Distorted or damaged foliage
possibleCauses: Lack of integrated pest management
Favorable environmental conditions for pests
solutions: Implement biological control measures (e.g., predatory insects)
Use insecticidal soap or neem oil
Maintain a clean growing environment
problems.adjustmentRecommendation: Focus on pest control strategies; nutrient adjustments are secondary.

problems.title: Environmental Stress from Temperature/Light Extremes
problems.description: Extreme temperatures or excessive light intensity can cause stress in hydroponic plants, affecting nutrient uptake and overall growth.
symptoms: Leaf scorch
Wilting
Stunted growth
possibleCauses: High temperatures
Excessive light intensity
Low humidity
solutions: Regulate ambient temperature
Provide shading or cooling systems
Increase humidity in the growing area
problems.adjustmentRecommendation: If stress is nutrient-related, reduce the nutrient concentration by about 10% while addressing environmental controls.

problems.title: Leggy or Elongated Seedlings
problems.description: Seedlings or young plants become tall, thin, and spindly due to suboptimal growing conditions, often related to lighting.
symptoms: Long, weak stems that cannot support the plant
Small or pale leaves on stretched stems
Seedlings may topple over
possibleCauses: Insufficient light intensity or duration
Grow light positioned too far from plants
Excessively high temperatures causing stretching
solutions: Increase light intensity or move light source closer
Extend the duration of light exposure if necessary
Maintain optimal temperature to prevent excessive stretching
problems.adjustmentRecommendation: Focus on improving light conditions (intensity and duration) rather than nutrient adjustments.

references.title: UGA Extension - Troubleshooting Problems in Hydroponics

problems.title: Poor Germination or Seedling Damping-off
problems.description: Seeds fail to germinate well or young seedlings collapse due to fungal disease (damping-off) or unfavorable germination conditions.
symptoms: Low or no seed sprouting
Seed coatings turning mushy or moldy
Seedlings collapsing at the base (thin, brown stem)
possibleCauses: Certain seeds (e.g., spinach) have naturally low germination in hydroponics
Water or medium temperature outside optimal range for germination
Overly wet conditions leading to fungal growth (damping-off)
solutions: Start seeds in a suitable medium or pre-germinate before transferring to hydroponics
Maintain proper temperature for germination (generally 70-80°F for many vegetables)
Ensure good air flow and avoid waterlogging seedlings; use clean water and sterilized media
problems.adjustmentRecommendation: Address environmental conditions (temperature, moisture) and sanitation rather than nutrient levels.

references.title: UGA Extension - Troubleshooting Problems in Hydroponics

problems.title: Tip Burn in Lettuce (Calcium Deficiency)
problems.description: New leaves in lettuce (especially head lettuce) develop brown, dead edges due to calcium not reaching rapidly growing tissue, often under high humidity or low transpiration.
symptoms: Brown, dead edges on new leaves (especially in head lettuce)
Scorched appearance on leaf tips or margins
Reduced head quality or marketability
possibleCauses: Calcium deficiency caused by low transpiration (often from high humidity)
Inadequate calcium in nutrient solution or imbalance
Rapid growth that outpaces calcium uptake
solutions: Increase air circulation around plants (use fans) to promote transpiration
Ensure sufficient calcium in the nutrient solution (consider adding calcium nitrate)
Maintain moderate humidity levels; avoid extremely humid, stagnant air
problems.adjustmentRecommendation: Add a calcium supplement (or adjust nutrient mix) by ~10% and improve airflow; monitor new leaf development.

references.title: UNH Extension - Hydroponics at Home (Calcium Deficiency)

problems.title: Interveinal Chlorosis on New Leaves (Iron Deficiency)
problems.description: New growth shows yellowing between the leaf veins while veins remain green, typically indicating iron deficiency or iron lockout due to high pH.
symptoms: Yellowing (chlorosis) between veins on young leaves
Green veins with yellow leaf tissue
In severe cases, new leaves may become almost white and stunted
possibleCauses: Nutrient solution pH too high (iron becomes unavailable)
Insufficient iron in the nutrient formulation
Nutrient antagonism (excess of other elements hindering iron uptake)
solutions: Test and adjust pH to optimal range (around 5.5–6.5) for iron availability
Add a chelated iron supplement to the nutrient solution
Balance nutrient levels (avoid excessive concentrations of phosphates or other metals that compete with iron)
problems.adjustmentRecommendation: Gradually lower pH and add iron chelate as needed; new growth should improve in color over 1-2 weeks.

references.title: Penn State Extension - Hydroponics Nutrient Deficiencies (Iron)

problems.title: Yellowing Between Veins on Older Leaves (Magnesium Deficiency)
problems.description: Older, lower leaves turn yellow between veins (veins stay green), which is characteristic of magnesium deficiency in many plants.
symptoms: Interveinal chlorosis on older or lower leaves
Green veins with yellow or pale areas between veins on affected leaves
In advanced cases, brown spots or edges on leaves; leaf drop
possibleCauses: Insufficient magnesium in the nutrient solution
High calcium or potassium levels causing Mg uptake antagonism
Nutrient solution pH too high, reducing magnesium availability
solutions: Add a magnesium supplement (e.g., magnesium sulfate/Epsom salt) to the nutrient solution
Check nutrient balance and reduce excess calcium or potassium if they are disproportionately high
Ensure pH is in the 5.5–6.5 range for optimal magnesium availability
problems.adjustmentRecommendation: Increase magnesium in the solution by ~10% and monitor older leaves; adjust overall nutrient balance if necessary.

references.title: Penn State Extension - Hydroponics Nutrient Deficiencies (Magnesium)

problems.title: Brown or Burnt Leaf Edges on Older Leaves (Potassium Deficiency)
problems.description: Older leaves develop yellowing and browning along the edges (margins), sometimes with spots, typically due to a lack of potassium.
symptoms: Yellowing or bronzing along the leaf margins of older leaves
Leaf edges turning brown and crispy (marginal scorch)
Possible dark spotting on leaves; overall plant may be weak or lanky
possibleCauses: Insufficient potassium levels in the nutrient solution
Excessive calcium, sodium, or ammonium in solution competing with potassium uptake
Using water with high sodium content leading to potassium uptake issues
solutions: Increase the potassium concentration in the nutrient mix (or use a bloom formula higher in K)
Ensure a balanced nutrient ratio and avoid over-supplying calcium or other antagonistic nutrients
Use a quality water source or install filters to reduce sodium and other impurities
problems.adjustmentRecommendation: Boost potassium by ~10-15% in the solution and remove severely damaged leaves; monitor new growth for improved coloration and strength.

references.title: Western Michigan University - Hydroponic Nutrient Deficiency Guide (Potassium)

problems.title: Stunted Growth with Purpling Leaves (Phosphorus Deficiency)
problems.description: Plants exhibit slow, stunted growth and may show a purple tint on older leaves or stems, especially under cold conditions, indicating a possible phosphorus deficiency.
symptoms: Slow, stunted overall growth
Older leaves dark green or purplish in color (especially underside of leaves or veins)
Delayed or sparse flowering and fruiting
possibleCauses: Insufficient phosphorus in the nutrient solution
Cool temperatures reducing phosphorus uptake
Nutrient imbalance (excessive iron/zinc can precipitate phosphorus or otherwise interfere)
solutions: Increase phosphorus content in the nutrient solution (consider a bloom booster higher in P)
Keep air and solution temperature in optimal range (around 65–75°F) to enhance uptake
Avoid oversupplying micronutrients that can bind with phosphorus; use fully soluble nutrient sources
problems.adjustmentRecommendation: Raise phosphorus levels by ~15% and ensure proper temperature; look for improved growth and less purpling on new growth over a couple of weeks.

references.title: Western Michigan University - Hydroponic Nutrient Deficiency Guide (Phosphorus)

problems.title: White Powdery Patches on Leaves (Powdery Mildew)
problems.description: Fuzzy white patches appear on leaf surfaces due to powdery mildew infection, common in conditions of high humidity and poor air circulation.
symptoms: White, powdery fungal growth on leaves or stems
Affected leaves may turn yellow or brown and distort
Fungal patches can spread to cover large portions of foliage
possibleCauses: High humidity and stale air (poor ventilation) around plants
Overcrowding of plants leading to limited airflow
Spores introduced from other infected plants or outdoors
solutions: Remove and destroy affected leaves to reduce spore spread
Improve air circulation (use fans, space plants apart) and reduce humidity
Apply a safe fungicide or remedy (like potassium bicarbonate, neem oil, or labeled fungicide) at first sign of mildew
problems.adjustmentRecommendation: No nutrient changes needed; focus on lowering humidity and treating plants with antifungal measures.

references.title: University of Maryland Extension - Powdery Mildew on Indoor Plants

problems.title: Gray Fuzzy Mold on Plants (Botrytis/Gray Mold)
problems.description: A gray, fuzzy mold grows on leaves, stems, or fruits (especially decaying or old tissue), typically caused by Botrytis cinerea in cool, humid conditions.
symptoms: Gray-brown fuzzy mold on affected areas of plants (flowers, fruits, or damaged leaves)
Water-soaked spots on leaves or petals that turn brown
Flowers or fruits may rot and develop gray mold
possibleCauses: Cool temperatures combined with high humidity, creating ideal conditions for Botrytis
Poor air circulation and presence of decaying plant material
Overcrowding of plants or any situation that keeps foliage wet for extended periods
solutions: Prune out and dispose of infected tissues immediately (don't compost indoors)
Increase air flow and reduce humidity in the growing area
Apply an appropriate fungicide if the outbreak is severe, to protect healthy tissue
Keep the growing area clean of dead leaves or debris where the fungus can harbor
problems.adjustmentRecommendation: Focus on environmental controls (temperature, humidity) and hygiene; nutrient adjustments are not effective against this issue.

references.title: Penn State Extension - Strawberry Gray Mold (Botrytis) Conditions

problems.title: Root Drying in NFT Channels
problems.description: Plants in a Nutrient Film Technique system begin to wilt or burn because their roots are not receiving enough water flow, causing them to dry out.
symptoms: Wilting or drooping plants, particularly far from the nutrient inlet
Dry, brittle roots in the NFT channels (white roots turning brown)
Leaf tips or edges may become crispy if dehydration continues
possibleCauses: Interruption in nutrient flow (pump failure or power outage)
Nutrient solution film too shallow or uneven, not reaching all roots
Roots overgrown and clogging the channel, causing overflow or uneven distribution
solutions: Immediately restore flow by fixing the pump or power supply
Ensure channels are properly sloped and unobstructed for even nutrient film distribution
Trim excessive roots and consider using larger channels or multiple channels to prevent blockage
Implement monitoring or alarms for pump function to catch failures early
problems.adjustmentRecommendation: Focus on mechanical fixes (restore flow); consider slightly reducing nutrient concentration temporarily if roots were damaged, to ease recovery.

references.title: Science in Hydroponics - NFT System Fragility (Flow Failures)

problems.title: Wilting in Aeroponics (Clogged Nozzles or Pump Failure)
problems.description: Plants in an aeroponic system wilt rapidly due to the nutrient mist supply being disrupted, often from clogged spray nozzles, pump failure, or timer issues.
symptoms: Sudden and severe wilting of plants across the system
Roots appearing dry and lacking the usual moisture
Leaf edges may become dry and curled if not addressed quickly
possibleCauses: Clogged misting nozzles (mineral deposits or debris blocking them)
Pump failure or power outage halting the misting cycle
Timer or control malfunction leading to infrequent or missed misting intervals
solutions: Unclog or replace blocked nozzles and use filters in the nutrient solution to prevent clogs
Restore pump operation or replace a failed pump; consider a backup pump in critical systems
Ensure the misting timer is functioning correctly and set to spray at appropriate intervals
Regularly maintain and clean the system to prevent future clogs (e.g., flush with clean water)
problems.adjustmentRecommendation: No nutrient concentration change needed; resume normal misting schedule and reduce plant stress (e.g., temporarily lower light intensity) until recovery.

references.title: Hypno Seeds - Common Aeroponics Problems (Nozzle Clogging)

problems.title: Uneven Watering in Drip System (Clogged Emitters)
problems.description: Some plants in a drip-irrigated hydroponic setup wilt or show nutrient deficiencies due to clogged emitters or uneven distribution of the nutrient solution.
symptoms: One or more plants wilting despite others being fine in the same system
Dry growing medium in pots of affected plants
Nutrient deficiency-like symptoms (yellowing, stunting) in some plants despite overall system feeding
possibleCauses: Mineral buildup or debris clogging the drip emitters
Insufficient pump pressure or tubing kinks leading to uneven flow
Algae or biofilm growth blocking tubing or emitters over time
solutions: Inspect and clean or replace clogged emitters; flush lines regularly
Use a filter on the nutrient reservoir output to catch particles before they reach emitters
Periodically run a cleaning solution (like dilute hydrogen peroxide or vinegar) through the system to dissolve mineral deposits
Maintain proper pump pressure and consider using pressure-compensating emitters for even flow
problems.adjustmentRecommendation: Restore even watering; after fixing, monitor the previously dry plants as they rehydrate (avoid overcompensating with excessive nutrients immediately).

problems.title: Improper Flood/Drain Timing in Ebb & Flow
problems.description: Plants in an ebb & flow system experience stress due to the flood cycles being too infrequent (causing dryness) or too frequent (causing waterlogging).
symptoms: Wilting between flood cycles if medium dries out too much
Yellowing or root rot symptoms if medium stays overly wet
Inconsistent growth across the grow bed
possibleCauses: Flood cycles scheduled too far apart, leading to periods of drought for roots
Flood duration too long or cycles too frequent, suffocating roots
Malfunctioning timer or pump causing irregular flood/drain patterns
solutions: Adjust timer to flood more frequently or for longer if plants were drying out (ensure medium stays moist but not bone dry between cycles)
If roots were waterlogged, reduce flood frequency or duration to allow more oxygen to reach roots
Ensure the pump and timer are functioning correctly and consistently
Observe plant and medium moisture and fine-tune the schedule as needed for that specific crop and medium
problems.adjustmentRecommendation: Modify the flood/drain schedule rather than nutrient levels; ensure each cycle properly balances water and oxygen for roots.

problems.title: Excess Foliage, No Flowers or Fruits
problems.description: Plants are healthy and green but produce few or no flowers and fruits, often due to an excess of nitrogen or imbalanced nutrients favoring vegetative growth over reproductive growth.
symptoms: Very lush, dark green plant growth
Few or no flower buds forming when expected
Flowers that do form may drop off (no fruit set)
possibleCauses: Nutrient formula too high in nitrogen and too low in phosphorus/potassium for the flowering stage
Overall EC might be too high, promoting vegetative growth
Inadequate light quality or photoperiod for flowering (if using artificial lighting)
solutions: Switch to a "bloom" nutrient formula with lower nitrogen and higher P/K as flowering time approaches
Slightly reduce overall feeding strength to encourage the plant to shift to reproductive mode
Make sure the plant is getting appropriate light (intensity and photoperiod) for flowering
problems.adjustmentRecommendation: Gradually decrease nitrogen by ~20% and increase phosphorus/potassium; monitor over the next 1-2 weeks for initiation of flowering.

references.title: UGA Extension - Troubleshooting Problems in Hydroponics

problems.title: Cold Stress (Low Temperature Issues)
problems.description: Plants exposed to temperatures below their optimal range exhibit slow growth and sometimes develop unusual coloration (such as purpling) or other stress symptoms.
symptoms: Slowed growth rate or temporarily halted growth
Older leaves may develop purple tints (especially underside) or stay darker green
Leaves might appear limp or curling in severe chill
Delayed flowering or fruiting in crops that should be blooming
possibleCauses: Air temperatures dropping too low for the plant variety (e.g., below 60°F for warm-season crops)
Cold nutrient solution temperature, which can slow nutrient uptake
Exposure to cold drafts or nights much cooler than days
solutions: Keep air temperature in the recommended range (use heaters if necessary during cold periods)
Maintain nutrient solution temperature around 65-70°F using aquarium heaters or insulation if needed
Avoid placing systems on cold floors or near sources of cold drafts; insulate tanks and grow beds
Gradually rewarm plants that have been exposed to cold to avoid shock
problems.adjustmentRecommendation: Focus on raising temperatures to optimal range; ensure adequate phosphorus if purpling occurred due to cold (as a secondary measure).

references.title: UGA Extension - Troubleshooting Problems in Hydroponics
